questions.text:
Arrange the following sites of ectopic pregnancy from the most common to the least common.
  1. Interstitium
  2. Isthmus
  3. Ampulla
  4. Fimbriae
questions.solution:
The order of the most common site to the least common site in the fallopian tube for ectopic pregnancy is ampulla>isthmus>fimbriae>interstitium.

An ectopic pregnancy is any pregnancy implanted outside of the endometrial cavity.

Extrauterine sites: The most common site of ectopic pregnancy is the extrauterine fallopian tube. 

  • Tubal - 97% (most common)
    • Ampulla - 55%
    • Isthmus
    • Infundibulum
    • Interstitium
  • Ovarian
  • Abdominal

Intrauterine ectopic sites:

  • Cervical
  • Caesarean scar 
  • Rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus
  • Heterotopic pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options.

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Prior ectopic pregnancy
  • Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy
  • Infertility
  • Artificial reproductive therapy
  • Endometriosis
  • Smoking
  • Maternal age >40 years
  • Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.text: The fall in which of the following hormone/s leads to endometrial sloughing in ectopic gestation?
questions.solution:
Endometrial sloughing in ectopic gestation is due to the fall in the levels of progesterone and hCG.

During normal pregnancy, endometrium is maintained by the high levels of hCG and progesterone. In ectopic pregnancy, a fall in the levels of these hormones will cause endometrial sloughing and uterine bleeding. If the decidua is expelled as a single piece through the cervix, it is called a decidual cast.

questions.text: Which type of tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage?
questions.solution:
Interstitial tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage i.e. at 12-16 weeks. This is because pregnancy at this site is closer to the uterine myometrium which provides support as pregnancy progresses. 

Isthmic and ampullary pregnancies terminate by tubal rupture. However, isthmic pregnancy ruptures earlier. Ampullary and infundibular pregnancy can terminate by tubal abortion as well.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in a patient with ruptured ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A shock index of >0.85 is seen in a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. There is massive blood loss (SBP<110 mmHg) sometimes leading to shock. 

The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP.

Condition Range of shock index
Normal value of shock index (non-pregnant) 0.5 - 0.7
Normal value of shock index in pregnancy (i.e) obstetrical shock index 0.7 - 0.8
Significant or massive blood loss 0.9 - 1.1

Option A: Sub-diaphragmatic blood irritates the phrenic nerve. This causes a referred pain at the shoulder tip. This is called as Danforth sign.

Option B: The expulsion of decidua in a single piece through the cervix is called a decidual cast. This is due to the fall in the levels of β hCG and progesterone.

Option C: Vertigo and syncope are due to reflex vasomotor disturbances due to peritoneal irritation from hemoperitoneum.

questions.text: A woman presented with complaints of amenorrhoea for 6 weeks and a history of prior ectopic pregnancy. Serial serum beta hCG levels were estimated in her. Which of the following findings will increase the suspicion of ectopic gestation in her?

choices.text: Low levels with prolonged doubling time
High levels with decreased doubling time

questions.solution:
Low levels of β hCG and prolonged doubling time increase the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.

Urine pregnancy test is very sensitive and found positive in most ectopic pregnancies. Hence, serial serum β hCG levels are estimated to detect ectopic pregnancy. In early normal pregnancy, the doubling time of β hCG concentrations in plasma is 1.4 to 2 days.

questions.text: A patient presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhoea and a positive UPT. TVS revealed a tubal ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following findings can be usually picked up on colour Doppler?

choices.text: Enhanced blood flow pattern in the uterine artery

questions.solution:
Ring of fire pattern is seen on color doppler in a tubal ectopic pregnancy. This is due to placental blood flow in the tubal pregnancy. 

This finding may also be seen in corpus luteum cysts but the wall is less echogenic compared to tubal ectopic.

Option A: There is an enhanced blood flow pattern outside the uterine cavity in case of ectopic pregnancy.

Option B: Arias-Stella reaction/phenomenon is a histological finding. It is an atypical endometrial change due to the action of progesterone on the endometrial tissue seen in normal, ectopic, and molar pregnancies.

On histology, there are:

  • large cells with abundant eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm
  • nuclear enlargement
  • hyperchromasia

Option D: Whirlpool sign refers to the twisted ovarian pedicle seen on USG of ovarian torsion.

questions.text: A pregnant woman came for routine antenatal USG. Which of the following features is suggestive of a pseudogestational sac?
questions.solution:
Central location is a feature of the pseudogestational sac seen in ectopic pregnancies.

Pseudogestational sac is a collection of fluid between the endometrial layers, surrounded by a thick decidua. Its presence increases the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.

Differences between pseudogestational sac and true gestational sac:

Feature Pseudogestational sac True gestational sac
Location within the endometrial cavity Central Eccentric
Shape  Usually ovoid Usually round
Fetal and yolk sac poles Absent Present
Double ring sign Absent Seen
Intradecidual sign Absent Seen

questions.text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum β hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy. 

If the level is ≥2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeat serum β hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:

  • Doubled - early intrauterine pregnancy
  • Decreased - abortion
  • Increased but less than doubled value - ectopic pregnancy

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Serum β hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass
  • Colour Doppler - ring of fire pattern
  • Laparoscopy 
  • Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi
  • Serum progesterone 
  • Culdocentesis 

Diagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial β-hCG monitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previous ectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with unruptured ectopic gestation. Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in this patient?

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level of 200 mIU/mL

questions.solution:
A gestational sac size of <4 cm is an indication of expectant management.

Expectant management is done only in the case of unruptured tubal pregnancy. In this, observation is done till there is spontaneous resolution. It can be done but is not preferred due to prolonged follow-up and uncertainty in resolution.

The indications are: 

  • Initial serum β hCG <1500 IU/L
  • Falling serum β hCG levels
  • Gestational sac size <4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity on TVS
  • No evidence of rupture or bleeding on TVS

questions.text: A primigravida in her first trimester came for a routine ANC. USG findings revealed an empty uterine cavity. Serum beta hCG was measured and was found to be 1700 IU/mL. All of the following drugs can be used in managing this patient except:
questions.solution:
Oxytocin is not used in the management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Indications for medical management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy:

  • Hemodynamically stable patient
  • Serum β hCG <5000 IU/L
  • Tubal diameter <4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • No intra-abdominal haemorrhage

Medical management of unruptured tubal ectopic:

  • Direct local therapy (laparoscopy or USG guidance) -
    • Methotrexate
    • Potassium chloride
    • Actinomycin
    • Hyperosmolar glucose
    • PGF2α
  • Systemic therapy - single dose of methotrexate 50 mg/m2 IM

Follow-up after medical management is done by measuring the decline in serial serum β hCG.

questions.text: A patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy is planned for medical management with methotrexate. What is the multi-dose protocol for this drug?
questions.solution:
In the multi-dose protocol, methotrexate is given at a dose of 1 mg/kg as an IM injection on alternate days 1, 3, 5, and 7.

This regimen is continued on alternating days until the hCG level drops by 15% over two days. Up to 4 doses may be given. Along with this, leucovorin rescue (folinic acid) is given at 0.1 mg/kg after 24 hrs (on days 2, 4, 6, and 8) to buffer the side effects of methotrexate.

MTX Protocol Multi-dose regimen Single-dose regimen
Dose 

1 mg/kg
(+ 0.1 mg/kg LEU)

50 mg/m2
(Body surface area)
Regimen Alternate daily doses  Day 0
hCG measurement Days 0, 1, 3, 5, 7 Days 0, 4, 7
Treatment success hCG declines >15% from the previous value hCG declines >15% between Day 4 and 7
When to administer additional dose   2nd, 3rd or 4th dose to be given if hCG does not decline 15% from the previous value. Maximum 4 doses   Second dose on Day 7 if hCG does not decline 15% 

 Note: If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L.

questions.text:
Which of the following must be avoided by a patient with tubal pregnancy on methotrexate?
  1. Sunlight exposure
  2. Sexual intercourse
  3. Dairy products
  4. NSAIDs
  5. Azithromycin
questions.solution:
Sunlight exposure, sexual intercourse and NSAIDs must be avoided when patients are on methotrexate therapy.

The following should be avoided when methotrexate therapy has been initiated for the treatment of ectopic gestation:

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs - can cause reduced renal blood flow and delay drug excretion
  • Alcohol - can predispose to concurrent hepatic enzyme elevation
  • Sunlight - may provoke methotrexate-related dermatitis
  • Sexual intercourse - can rupture the ectopic pregnancy
  • Phenytoin, tetracyclines, salicylates, and sulfonamides - can increase serum methotrexate levels

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state with complaints of bleeding PV  associated with abdominal pain and a history of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. On examination, BP was 90/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and UPT was positive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy which must be immediately managed with simultaneous resuscitation and laparotomy. On laparotomy, salpingectomy is the definitive surgery. 

Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features:

  • Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV
  • Abdominal pain 
  • Hemodynamically unstable 
  • Urine pregnancy test - positive

Surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy, performed either through laparoscopy or laparotomy.

Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation and stabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid and surgical exploration. 

Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with preservation of the ipsilateral ovary and its vascular supply. 

For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged, salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of the products of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoes salpingostomy, it is important check the β-hCG level on a weekly basis to ensure that it reaches zero.

The image given below shows a laparoscopic visualization of a tubal pregnancy.

questions.text:
Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
1) Abdominal A) Spiegelberg
2) Cervical B) Studdiford
3) Cornual C) Rubin
4) Ovarian
questions.solution:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
Abdominal Studdiford
Cervical Rubin
Ovarian  Spiegelberg

Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament.

Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface.

Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os.

questions.text: An O-ve primigravida underwent surgery for ectopic pregnancy at 13 weeks of gestation. What will be the dose of anti-D immunoglobulin to be given to her?
questions.solution:
Anti-D is given at a dose of 300 μg intramuscularly for alloimmunization after surgical management of ectopic pregnancy.

The dose of anti-D in a surgically treated case of ectopic is 50 μg if gestation <12 weeks. If the gestation is >12 weeks, 300 μg of anti-D is given intramuscularly. 

Anti-D is not given when the ectopic is treated with medical methods.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient (G2P0A1) with a history of FSH therapy and in vitro fertilization presented with lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and vaginal discharge. On examination, she was hemodynamically stable. Transvaginal ultrasound showed a viable intrauterine pregnancy of 8 weeks associated with a heterogeneous right adnexal mass showing a positive bagel sign. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heterotopic pregnancy. Surgery is the ideal treatment in heterotopic pregnancy.

A normal uterine pregnancy co-existing with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy is termed a heterotopic pregnancy. Although heterotopic pregnancy can occur spontaneously, it is more likely after ART and ovulation induction.

Tubal ring sign also referred to as bagel sign is one of the ultrasound signs of a tubal ectopic. It comprises an echogenic ring that surrounds an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. 

USG image showing bagel sign or tubal ring sign:

Methotrexate is not to be given as it harms even the normal intrauterine fetus. Although potassium chloride may be injected into the sac of the ectopic, the safer method would be surgery to remove the ectopic.

questions.text: Methotrexate was administered to a patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy. At what serum beta hCG levels will this drug be most effective?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is most effective when given at β hCG levels are <5000 IU/L.

Methotrexate is given at a dose of 50 mg/m2 of body surface area. Monitoring is done by measuring β hCG levels on days 4 and 7. If the decline is ≥15% of the initial value, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. If the decline is <15%, a 2nd dose of methotrexate is given on day 7.

questions.text: Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of _____________
questions.solution:
Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants on the peritoneal surface of the abdomen.

Studdiford’s criteria:

  1. The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy.
  2. No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula.
  3. The presence of pregnancy, related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation

Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:

  • Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria); Rubin's criteria (histological criteria)
  • Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria

Although the incidence of abdominal pregnancy is only 1 in 10,000, diagnosis at the earliest is of utmost importance due to the possible complications. The classic ultrasound finding is the absence of myometrial tissue between the maternal bladder and the conceptus.
